> > (actually
> > because of the real split-game dynamics, there are
> > 5).
>
> What do you mean by "split-game dynamics"?

So, for example take a 5x5 game board:

- - - - -
- - - - -
- - * * *
* * * * *
* * * * *


The "-"s represent one half of the board, and the "*" the other. On one
half, we learn the game where ones are initial, and zeros are played by
the NN, and on the other half, zeros are initial, etc. However, along the
border, we could get something like this:

- - - - -
- - - - -
- 0 * * *
* 1 * * *
* * * * *

Where the NN played both the 0, and the 1. Then, by the normal game
scoring method, there would be a point generated, because a 0 is next to a
one. This is an erroneous point, i.e. the NN is not learning to capture
pre-existing stones, instead, it is learning to capture its own stones.
This just results from the "split-game" hack that I used to promote
modularization. So, "split-game" dynamics just refers to avoiding this by
treating the two halves as separate and not touching.

> I'm extremely interested in indirect encoding in the
> context of NEAT.  We have some ideas about various
> approaches to take, and at some point we'd probably
> like to do a comparison with standard NEAT, as well as
> your approach to modularity.  Is the code available
> somewhere now?

No the code isn't available yet. Its not particularly clean, or well
documented, and I don't have a lot of time to make it so now (I will
probably over the summer if there is enough interest). If you need it
before then, I can send it to you, and I can go over some of the
implementation quirks with you. Otherwise just keep poking me and I'll
make a public release.

I'm also very interested in an indirect encoding using NEAT, so I'd
definitely like to see the results of such a comparison.

Joe
